title: Easy as 1,2,3 to skip bank fees sting
text:
Easy as 1,2,3 to skip bank fees sting Easy as 1,2,3 to skip bank fees sting MILLIONS who signed up to the popular Santander 123 current account are being urged to vote with their feet as the bank hikes its fees by a shocking 150 per cent. PUBLISHED: 15:32, Wed, Sep 16, 2015 | UPDATED: 15:54, Wed, Sep 16, 2015 GETTY If you are not happy with your bank there are plenty of others offering incentives 
Many may be tempted to switch to Tesco Bank, which has just scrapped the £5 monthly fee on its current account for both new and existing customers. 
Switching accounts is easier than ever and plenty of banks are battling for your business. 
Today is the second anniversary of the Current Account Switch Service that has already helped more than two million Britons find a better current account. 
The service makes it simpler to switch accounts and take your balance and regular payments with you. 
If you are not happy with your bank it may be time to move on. Santander 123 is increasing the annual account fee it charges its 3.6 million customers from £24 to £60 a year – a rise of 150 per cent. 
Hannah Maundrell, the editor-in-chief at personal finance website Money.co.uk, accused Santander of operating a “Venus flytrap” to lure in new customers before making the deal less attractive. 
Santander 123 still offers a series of benefits, including cashback on your utility, council tax, mobile phone and broadband direct debits. 
It also pays 3 per cent interest on balances between £3,000 and £20,000. Related articles Can we rely on stock markets? 
Maundrell said: “Higher charges and caps on cashback mean the number of customers who benefit will be reduced significantly.” 
Head of banking at MoneySupermarket.com, Kevin Mountford said Santander 123 customers with balances above £4,500 may still be in pocket but anybody with less should consider moving on : “Santander’s changes do not come into force until January 11 next year so you have time to work out your options.” 
Nicolas Frankcom, money expert at comparison site uSwitch.com, said: “Santander did not win any of our customer services awards this year and it may be time for their customers to see if they are still getting value for money.” 
He added: “Competition in the current account market is hotting up with banks such as Halifax, TSB and Clydesdale bringing in switching incentives and lots of accounts on the market are still offering high interest on balances.” GETTY Some banks will give you a cash incentive to switch Current Accounts 
Nationwide FlexDirect pays 5 per cent on the first £2,500 in your account and TSB Classic Plus pays 5 per cent on up to £2,000. 
Other banks give you a cash incentive to switch. Santander did not win any of our customer services awards this year and it may be time for their customers to see if they are still getting value for money Nicholas Frankcom, uSwitch.com 
The popular First Direct account will give you £150 if you apply through MoneySupermarket, while Clydesdale and Yorkshire Banks also offer a £150 cash incentive to new customers. 
Halifax’s Reward Current Account pays £125 cashback to those using its dedicated switching service and up to 15 per cent cashback when using its debit card with selected retailers. 
And Tesco is now a best buy after scrapping its £5 monthly fee. 
Charlotte Nelson, finance expert at MoneyFacts.co.uk, said. “This makes its account more straightforward and also more inclusive, especially for those on lower incomes.” 
Tesco offers other benefits. “It pays 3 per cent on balances up to £3,000 and has low overdraft charges, which means it is likely to be a popular choice for both savers and borrowers alike,” she said. Related articles Cheapest ever home loans: Rates to fall again 
A total of 40 banks, almost the entire market, have now signed up to the Current Account Switch Service. 
This gives you a reliable and stress-free way of switching current accounts and has helped support the growth of new challenger banks such as Aldermore, Metro Bank, Tesco Bank, Shawbrook Bank and Virgin Money. 
Nine out of 10 customers are satisfied with almost 100 per cent of switches completing on their chosen day. 
And more than half a million people have used the service in the first half of this year. 
Once you have opened a current account with a new bank, the service will transfer your balance and all the activity from your old account before closing it. 
The service is backed by the Current Account Switch Guarantee, which promises to reimburse you any fees or charges incurred.
